title: Seasoning date for foreclosure that has been discharged in chapter 7
question: Hello, I've been trying to look for an answer. I filed chapter7 bankruptcy and my house was included in it. My bankruptcy was discharged in 2010 but the foreclosure was not completed until Nov 2011 My question is, why do the banks have to wait for the seasoning date of foreclosure when the house was included in the bankruptcy and was included in the discharged debts?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Automatic stays in bankruptcy,Bankruptcy documents,Credit score,Credit,Debt,Lien,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate finances,Foreclosure,Short sales,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate
answers: If you are talking about FHA loans, there is a provision that allows the lender to look to the bankruptcy date and NOT the foreclosure date IF the foreclosure delay was all on the lender. Is that what you were looking for?

The bank has to comply also with NON bankruptcy laws. Once the Bankruptcy automatic stay is gone, either by way of Motion or when the case is closed; the bank is placed in the position it was before the filing of the petition. If you filed the BK petition the day before the "Trustee Sale" date most likely the bank will not delay much after the stay is removed.

On the other hand, if you filed before the foreclosure process began, the bank has to follow a lengthy foreclosure process

Let me give you a ROUGH time line for foreclosure:

You stopped making payments to your house and start receiving letters from your letter reminding you of the payments for about two to three months, with parallel phone calls.

Then, after that the letters become more aggressive, for an additional two to three months with more often parallel phone calls.

Then the bank is required to give you notice of its intention to foreclose before the actual statutory "Notice of Default" and also is required to inform you of your election to apply for a Hamp "loan modification" and or "short Sale".

Once you reach the statutory "Notice of Default " with the required recording in the county recorders office, mailing and posting in front of your door, you will have another 90 days. This is done through a "Trustee" (not a BK trustee but the "Deed of Trust" Trustee)

After those 90 days has passed the lender, through the trustee, have to record a "Trustee Sale " Notice 21 days before the actual public sale (in addition to the mailing and posting).

Then after the foreclosure sale the lender has to give 3-day notice and 90 day notice to tenants in your house.

After that the Unlawful Detainer process another 45 to 90 days (depending on the lender, attorney handling the case)

As you can see, it is a tedious process and sometimes, depending on the lender, takes over a year from the first payment skipped to the actual eviction.

This time lien is just to give you an idea how the process work and it is not intended to give you an exact timing just a fair estimate.

I'll hazard a guess about what you mean by the "seasoning date". I'll assume that you are interested in obtaining a home loan sometime in the future. Banks/lenders and the agencies that insure home loans have different rules about how long you must wait if there is a bankruptcy filing in your credit history and how long you must wait if there is a foreclosure sale in your credit history. Your best bet is to check with an experienced mortgage broker for all the guideline lending rules that are currently in effect. Bear in mind that these rules are subject to change and often do change. In the mean time, you should focus on building up your credit score through the use of credit so that you will be in a good position to obtain a home loan once enough time has passed since your bankruptcy case filing and/or the foreclosure sale. I hope this answer helps.
Good luck!
